entry.et: Middle English collecte, from Anglo-French, from Medieval Latin collecta (short for oratio ad collectam prayer upon assembly), from Late Latin, assembly, from Latin, assemblage, from feminine of collectus

def.dt: :a short prayer comprising an invocation, petition, and conclusion
:one preceding the eucharistic Epistle and varying with the day

entry.et: Latin collectus, past participle of colligere to collect, from com- + legere to gather legend

def.dt: :to bring together into one body or place
:to gather or exact from a number of persons or sources collect taxes
:to gather an accumulation of (objects) especially as a hobby collects stamps
:to gain or regain control of collect his thoughts
:to claim as due and receive payment for
:pick up went to collect her at the train station
:to come together in a band, group, or mass :gather
:to receive payment collecting on the insurance
:to be paid for by the receiver

entry.et: partly from Latin recollectus, past participle of recolligere, from re- + colligere to collect; partly from re- + collect
